answers.author: Barry Crook
answers.text:
In no particular order:
-- getting folks to attend (we find that providing food helps)
-- creating an agenda that is not "open ended", yet allows people to feel they have some input into creating what they are to consider and opine about
-- keeping discourse "civil", i.e. letting people be "hard on the issues" not on the people . . . getting everyone to agree in advance that although we may disagree on policy, we all care about the community
-- getting people to accept that the opportunity to provide input does not mean your input will prevail . . . that the proof of engagement is not "you win"
-- getting folks to agree that a decision will be made and that the Council is the legitimate body to make the decision 
-- getting folks to agree that a decision made is not just another excuse to start over when the decision disagrees with yours
-- keeping the process time-bound so something does get decided on a schedule that has meaning
-- providing a wide variety of methods and techniques for engagement to occur -- not everyone wants to participate in the form of a 3-minute speech in front of an assembled elected body . . . so you have to come up with a variety of methods to suit the wide variety of ways people want to engage and be engaged by.

answers.author: Robert Carty
answers.text:
One major issue I had working with public works and community engagement was getting buy-in from contractors and senior engineers that it was even necessary. Even though senior management, department directors, and the manager made it a policy the PIOs were still seen as fly-in-soup. It took time and results to win them over, which we eventually did.
The second greatest challenge was building trust with the community, in an environment where any past or current 'city' issue impacted perception of your work, department, credibility, reliability. 
Attendance is always an issue, but when they see value in the meetings or know it's important that usually wasn't a problem once we built a relationship. I found that developing key relationships with a handful of people in the community worked as they would then muster their neighbors to attend, and explain why their participation or attendance was important.

answers.author: Dave Overfelt
answers.text:
Getting people engaged can be difficult, particularly if your only method of engagement is the standard public meeting.  If you want broader engagement you have to make the process interesting, exciting, and rewarding.  Generally, public meetings have a bad name, particularly since people go to City Council meetings (often the only interaction they can have with local governance) and find out that they are incredibly boring and most of the decisions have already been made.  I think a good example of innovative and ongoing engagement can be found here: http://www.manorlabs.org/.  The key here is to build a relationship with members of your community instead of trying to have a meeting and hoping people show up.  By showing people that you are interested in hearing what they have to say and that you will act on the things they want to see happen, you can build trust and increase your community's interest in engaging.
Although we don't focus directly on the problem of gathering greater levels of engagement, you may be interested in a series of blog posts we wrote on Structuring Public Engagement: http://buildingdialogue.wordpress.com/2010/11/23/structuring-engagement-series/
